bright lines from a dark ground, finally all 
the group disappeared. The groups (b),(c)
and (d) remained nearly unchanged; <s>but<\s> there appeared 
only two bright lines of (c), the place corres 
ponding to the two following ones being very 
brilliant.
The whole spectrum was divided into large 
fields, similar to the fields we described in 
the case of the flame of cyanogen fed with 
oxygen. But in this <s>new<\s> case each field is 
bounded at its more refracted and shadowed 
extremity by the first bright line of a charac 
teristic group, the following lines bordered by 
shading, rise from the lightest part of the adjacent 
<s>group<\s> field. In the new instance the fields are not 
bounded in the same way. After the group 
(a) disappeared, there is a differently shadowed 
dark space, extending to the place of the third 
bright line of that group. In the remaining 
part of the spectrum we may distinguish 
seven shadowed fields. The first goes a little beyond 
the first bright line of the group (b), where 
it is bounded by a transverse line, <u>bisecting<\u> [dividing] the 
band formed by the two first lines of the group,
into a dark less refracted and a light more 
refracted part. Accordingly, the first bright 
line rises from the dark end of the first field,
the remaining lines from the light end of 
the second field. The second field does not 
reach the first bright line of the following 
group (c), this line being nearly equally 
distant from the extremity of the field and the 
next line of the same group. The third field goes
